moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nf6: Tarrasch plays the Two Knights' Defense.
moves.4. d4: His opponent knows the book line.
moves.5. O-O: White goes for quick development instead of the immediate recapture.
moves.8. h3: Keeping Black cramped by preventing 8... B-N5. Black intends ...N-Q2, ... B-B3 and ...N/2-K4.
moves.8... Re8: Played with singular lack of judgment. Black should have played 8... N-Q2 immediately.
moves.9. Re1: Now that Black his weakened his KB2, he can no longer move his King Knight from KB3 to Q2. His King-side would be weakened beyond endurance.
moves.9... Nd7: Instead of 9... N-K4, which would at least offer temporary relief, Black stumbles into a fatal trap.
moves.11... Kxe6: On any other move, Black loses his Queen.
moves.13. Qf5#: A brilliant win for the amateur.
